comments.commentBody:
I posted several links below. Try this one for starters, it's quite informative, and well presented, it might help if your mind is open. However, you cannot refuse to look at the vast majority of science, well represented here at the NYTimes and by every expert organization worldwide, and claim to be a "skeptic".

This TED talk covers some of the ideas and ways of observing and modeling our amazing planet and climate:
"Gavin Schmidt: The emergent patterns of climate change"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JrJJxn-gCdo

I can hope, but the way you use "falsify" sounds clever and is largely meaningless in this context. What the science is, the simple physics about heat-trapping greenhouse gases increasing energy in the system, is uncontroversial. Science is not a religion but a way of evaluating the likelihood/probability of things. Gravity and the sun rising in the east are also only probably but even more likely than our current predicament being on the increase.
Not sure that QALY-dependent decision making would fly here, anyway, since that would effectively discriminate against the handicapped and the chronically ill.

Thank you for this analysis.   The political discourse has degenerated to bold display of willful  ignorance. And it has permeated to all fabric of the society aided by the media.  The gun safety debate; small and big government;  school choice,  abortion, money in politics,  religion and state.  The least goes on.  How otherwise we'll educated population could allow  itself to be so deceived beats imagination.  Propaganda.  Ideology.  Self-interest.  You peak. One could only hope we have reacheda turning point for humanity.  But to see the same folks  that boldly took a country and the world to Iraq with false evidences which were known at the time common up on stage, again  propagating the same ideology makes one to wonder if society has learned anything.

Kenneth,

It's very easy to write "Put providers on salaries commensurate with their skills, training, output and quality" but you would also need to explain just how those four criteria would be determined and what level of salary would be appropriate. As a very recently retired podiatrist, with a very modest savings account, I have always been a proponent of Medicare for all/universal healthcare. Having occasionally been excluded from insurance panels "because we have enough of your specialty already," or changes in Medicaid reimbursement (I participated for all of my 36 years in practice) that decreased participating providers income by 20% since 1990, I know how difficult and expensive it can be to practice in America. Want to truly rein in healthcare costs? Eliminate, not change, ALL private health insurance companies. Medicare, with all its faults and limitations, operates a 3-5% administrative overhead, while all other insurers have 17-25%. A quarter of your insurance premiums going for administrative costs? There's your waste in healthcare, not us greedy providers, most of whom are honest hard-working individuals trying to make a living in an extremely competitive, expensive, and litigious environment.
My malpractice premium in 1979 was $600/YEAR. When I quit last month, it was slightly less than $1,100/MONTH, and that was a discount because I was sued just once in 36 years. Don't feel sorry for me, I made a reasonable living, pity the new docs.

Thanks for your perspective, foot doc. And (off-topic, I know) may I say I admire podiatrists greatly. They have done great work with my diabetic patients, who I always refer to a podiatrist for any and all foot issues.
Thanks JenD.  I know that much of what I wrote was also off-topic, but a response to KennethV's commentary was needed.

Just to put a little perspective on this whole matter of $25 cataract surgery:

Cataract surgery of this type is "operator dependent" to a greater degree than other types of cataract surgery. Not every ophthalmologist has the skills required to do this. So, why not just limit these procedures to those who are skilled? We don't have enough ophthalmologists to cover our aging population as it is, and if we take away the prospect of their earning a decent enough living, we'll have even fewer ophthalmologists.

There is no such thing as a $25 /anything/ medical in the US in the 21st C. There are facilities to maintain, physicians and assistants to train, huge costs of doing business in medicine, including medical malpractice liability, which translates into high premiums, especially for surgeons. (I am not one.) And then there's the "profit incentive" of providers, health insurance companies, hospitals, etc.

Want to start to put and end all this? Go single payer, as in Medicare for all, control costs and fees, put providers on salaries commensurate with their skills, training, output and quality, substitute a no-fault liability and/or honest, objective arbitration for the current med-mal system that benefits lawyers more than patients, and enact a fair progressive taxation system to cover the costs. Of course, there would be bumps in the road.

Wait! That's socialism, isn't it?! Well, then let's just keep on doing what we're doing--it's working so well for everyone, no?

@Gwen - Exactly - I am a trained, experienced, well-educated, and not-impoverished real estate professional, yet it required my vigilance, aggression, meticulous record-keeping, and obnoxious persistence to get Chase to back off. So I read the comments that blame the victim or assume bad faith and say, ''they haven't a clue.''

I agree with Bernie Sanders. But, I'll vote for Hillary, because, frankly, I think she can be much more effective against these operators. They are slimy, slippery, and filthy rich. They are the private schooled brats with entitlement emblazoned in their Id. Shame is not an option for changing their behavior. Only fact, relentless persistence, and the danger of jail will bring them to heel, and for that - my vote goes to Hillary, who has the spine and the stuff, as Bill well knows. There's a good reason the GOP treats her with such hatred calling her a witch, ''Hidabeast' and worse - it is fear. They fear her. I think she's great. I don't care if she uses her own private server, and I certainly don't care if she insulates her personal email from her Linkdin and FB accounts - God Knows I DO!
It's  new world: Prepaid cellphones you can give any name and are hard to track.  NY Times-- thanks for a good much needed cautionary tale.

Bruni demands others pay attention based to the auhority of his own pain, the pain of being misunderstood.

When Bruni shills for phony consevative republicans telling whoppers like Rubio, others' pain doesn't even register with him.

The vote wasn't driven simply by ignorance; it was driven by fear, carefully cultivated and financed by well-known homophobes. Bruni is right to marvel at the "cynical political calculations", but should also marvel at how effective they were.
Readers should also note that the voter turnout was just under 27%. The HERO ordinance was defeated by 16% of registered voters.

This vote was driven by ignorance. Most of these voters have never knowingly met a transgender individual.

I say knowingly because there are many of us, like myself, who have an easier time presenting as our target gender. We got lucky: not too tall, no broad shoulders or facial features that give away our original sex. No one ever stops us from using the bathroom. We blend in, become invisible. If a casual acquaintance finds out that we are trans, there's usually a moment of shock ("I never would have guessed!"), but not rejection.

And that's why I know that this is not really about transgender people in general, but about making certain transfolks go back into the shadows. This is about appearance, about being visibly trans. This is about the transwoman who's 6'5" with linebacker shoulders and a chiseled jaw, not someone like me who hide in plain sight.

Dr. King's dream was that we judge people not by their outward appearance, but by the content of their character. And yet here we are, pushing the visibly trans into the margins of society because of their appearance. We are better than this.
Think letter grade.

Since Gerald always refuses to acknowledge the massive, nearly incalculable role of government funded basic scientific research in economic growth, may I suggest he go without any of the things such research has produced. Just to start off, you can give up your GPS, computer, cell phone, internet, vaccines, and MRIs. Unfortunately a full list is too long for a hundred of these comment boxes.

And considering those barbers use electric powered clippers, with precision machined blades that rely on computer controlled machinery, you may want to forgo your next haircut too.

the cost of the drug is the ultimate death panel.    America should go the cheapest route of banning speculation, funding research and getting rid of second parties who do a poor job keeping down costs.   It would cheaper for the  Federal government to run the program as in other countries.
What goes around comes around. You are either paying it through your taxes or premiums. Fail to see the difference.

"Because we all pay, all Americans have to have a voice in determining value."

That statement is patently false. We aren't all paying, and those who are paying something are not paying equal amounts of either taxes or insurance premiums. The question is, should someone who is heavily or fully subsidized by others be allowed to determine what sort of care those others get? That should be a moot point, however, since we were assured by those crafting the ACA that the dreaded death panels would never be an issue.

How is this complicated? A judge can determine that apparent fraud negates the contract and return title to the original owner.
The problem is the Real Estate industries vice grip on the NYC/NYS legal system and the national subservience to property rights over human rights.
If Moshe grabbed an old ladies pocket book on the N train, he'd be in Rikers for 3 years.
Why? Wordplay is for all. Didn't find your comment amusing. Sorry.

Beejay, Dr W is one of the most gentle and gentlemanly of commenters, whose only weakness is one he shares with me: the inability to resist any pun, and probably the speed with which he translates from germination to transmission.

This might serve as apology for me also, since I made a somewhat similar observation, and also meant no evil.

Reporting in late today (almost 7 EST) -- muchas gracias  for that nice comment.  I do admit to bouts of paronomasia.  It can be addictive.  I also sometimes do that to get Martin's reaction, and I have actually succeeded with one or two "gotchas".
Not a good puzzle for stutterers.  :-)

Someone forged my name on a lis pendens and stole someone's house while I sat in jail. I wrote to the fbi, us attorney, new jersey prosecutors office and never heard any response. In the end of the day, the Title company paid the bank for the loss of the theft. Trust me, once these thieves sit in jail, they will never do this crime again. The lawyers representing these crooks should be investigated because they breached the public trust. I wrote about this on amazon.com entitled,http://www.amazon.com/Dont-victim-Identity-Theft-Fraud-ebook/dp/B014LRVBBE

It would seem NY state and the counties in question bear the burden of restoring the homeowners to their properties unless they can prove the transactions were indeed legitimate. NY state authorities create and demand compliance to a system wholly inadequate to the task for which they are responsible. In this matter, any vulnerable owner is at risk to losing their property by a mere forgery, with the blessings of the county clerk.
Check earliest comments -- someone beat me to this one.

I'm so sorry that the way people have described transgender identity to you has caused you so much pain. Nobody should ever tell another person how to speak about their own body. That is not right and again, I am terribly sorry that it happened to you.

However, I think the people you have talked to about what gender identity means have either been deeply mistaken, or have simply failed to communicate effectively and accurately.

Gender identity is not based on behavior. That is gender expression and/or gender roles. Gender identity is the deeply set, innate sense of who one is as a person along the axis of sex/gender. Author and biologist Julia Serano coined the (undeniably more accurate, in my opinion) term Subconscious Sex.

It can be extremely difficult and frustrating to describe what it feels like to have a subconscious sex that differs from the sex of your chromosomes and genitals to someone who has never experienced such a disconnect. For this reason, some trans people have erroneously relied on gendered ideas of behaviors, interests, fashion, and the like to try to explain. But this is done out of frustration and desperation, not out of truth.

This is one of the most sickening articles I've ever read that did not involve violence. We all need shelter. To paraphrase the old saying, a person's home is their castle. For many people, their home is their most valuable asset. There is something so very depraved about preying on elderly and desperate people to steal their homes and force them out out on the street.

The people who perpetrate these crimes are sociopaths. They should go be put away for many, many years. Any lawyer involved should be disbarred.

The first role of government is to protect its citizens. The victims should get their homes back or be fully compensated for their losses by a government that has failed its duty to protect them.

This week we've read about legal but unfair arbitration contracts that benefit companies over victims. Now this. Our laws are failing the average person. It's hard not to feel this is the result of 35 years of Republican "government is the problem" propaganda. Our society is falling apart, but half the country doesn't understand why.
We have even more law enforcement diverted to terrorism, far beyond its threat (medical setting hygiene failures and distracted drivers kill far more of us.)
Most of these people do not get the company's information via a television commercial. They are approached directly by these people who scanned public records looking for potential victims.

That makes zero sense, whether you support Trump or not.  The people being victimized here are property owners and the victimizers are LLC owners, I guess you'd want to disqualify corporate types instead, like Carly Fiona or Romney.
I don't mind disqualifying Trump, Fiorina, Romney, Rubio, Cruz, and that's just for starters.

This story should alone disqualify Donald Trump from the presidency. If there is one thing America does not need, it is its first landlord-president. This is a field that makes Volkswagen and Exxon Mobil look like paragons of business ethics in comparison.

Reading this reminds me to practice giving to people, rather than
taking advantage of others, for personal gain.
Truly heinous. One hopes the attorney general's office, the DA's office  and others will pursue this vigorously.   Very long criminal sentences seem absolutely appropriate.

I was thinking the same, why doesn't Mr Bigbucks come home one day to find the new owners of his Mcmansion sitting in his driveway with their moving van? Perhaps the perpetrators of these schemes expect people who buy Mcmansions to do a lot of due diligence, and so the chance of getting caught is increased, but even that doesn't hold up.  Most buyers of even dodgy properties do due diligence.

Freedom! Liberty! GOP!

No American can be deprived the right to lie, cheat, and steal his fellow countrymen for money. It's what made America great! A great nation of con men.

When you hear the right banging on about freedom this is most of what they mean - the freedom to do anything for money and usually get away with it.

What is insane about this story is, apparently, someone can forge your signature and sell or take over your propert, without your ever even knowing about them, and "the law" is so convoluted, the courts and givernment so utterly incompetent, that you will lose your property. That doesn't have to be a house or property. It could be your car, your IRA, anything at all.

This was fantastic. It turned out like a pro pie. My go to recipe from now on.
- As noted, 2.5 cups is a lot more than 300 grams. I used 310 and it was a great crust (mixed all by hand).
- Like others, I put my pie on the bottom shelf. I shaved :10 off the final bake time (convection bake) with good results.
- Used a local apple butter that had rosemary in it.
- I did use the vodka and honey crisp apples.
